Title: Mysteriously congruent circles (geometry problem with nine circles in an isosceles triangle)
Content: In the diagram below, circles of the same color are congruent. Wherever things look tangent, they are tangent. The distance between the blue circles' centres is unspecified. Show that the red circle is congruent with the orange circles. Based on experiments on Desmos, it seems that the red circle is congruent with the orange circles, no matter the distance between the blue circles' centres, as long as the tangent relationships in the original diagram are preserved. The blue circles can even intersect each other. ( Additional findings: For the diagram on the right, in which the orange circles are tangent to the bottom blue circle, further investigation suggests that the largest circle inscribed in the intersection of the blue circles has the same radius as the green circles; and a circle inscribed in the triangle has exactly three times the radius of the red and orange circles.) My attempt The idea is to assume that the blue circles have radius $1$ , and define $p$ as half the distance between the blue circles. Then express everything in terms of $p$ . Draw a new circle $K$ with the same radius as the red circle, tangent to the base and right side of the triangle. Then show that $K$ is tangent to the lower right green circle, so $K$ must be the right orange circle, so the right orange circle must have the same radius as the red circle. Label points: $A$ and $C$ are the centres of the higher and lower blue circles, respectively. $B$ is the midpoint of $A$ and $C$ . $E$ is the centre of the higher right green circle. $F$ is the tangent point between the two right green circles. $G$ is the tangent point between the higher blue circle and the right side of the triangle. $H$ is the tangent point between the higher right green circle and the right side of the triangle. $D$ is on $AG$ such that $DE\parallel GH$ . Define: Assume that the radius of the blue circles is $1$ . $p$ is the signed distance from $B$ to the top of the lower blue circle. $q$ is the distance between the top vertex of the triangle and the top of the red circle. $a$ is the radius of the green circles. $b$ is the radius of the red circle. $\theta$ is half the angle at the top vertex of the triangle. Angle chasing shows that: $$\angle DEB =\angle BCF$$ So: $$\angle DEA+\angle AEB =\angle BCE+\angle ECF$$ $$\arcsin\left(\frac{1-a}{1+a}\right)+\arcsin\left(\frac{1+p}{1+a}\right)=\arccos\left(\frac{1+p}{1+a}\right)+\arcsin\left(\frac{a}{1+a}\right)\tag{1}$$ In principle, equation $(1)$ gives $a$ in terms of $p$ . Express $\theta$ in terms of $p$ : $$\theta=\frac{\pi}{2}-\angle DEB=\frac{\pi}{2}-\arcsin\left(\frac{1-a}{1+a}\right)-\arcsin\left(\frac{1+p}{1+a}\right)$$ Express $q$ and $b$ in terms of $p$ : $$\csc\theta=\frac{b+q}{q}\implies q=b(\csc\theta-1)$$ $$\csc\theta=1+2b+q=1+b(\csc\theta+1)\implies b=\frac{1-\sin\theta}{1+\sin\theta}$$ Superimpose cartesian axes, with the origin at the midpoint of the base of the triangle. Express the equation of the right side of the triangle in terms of $p$ : $$y=(-\cot\theta)x+4+q+2b+2p$$ Draw a new circle $K$ with radius $b$ , tangent to the base of the triangle and the right side of the triangle. Express the equation of $K$ in terms of $p$ : $$\left(x-\left(\frac{4+q+2b+2p}{\cot\theta}-b\cot\left(\frac{\arcsin\left(\frac{1-a}{1+a}\right)+\arcsin\left(\frac{1+p}{1+a}\right)}{2}\right)\right)\right)^2+\left(y-b\right)^2=b^2$$ Express the equation of the lower right green circle in terms of $p$ : $$\left(x-(1+a)\sin T\right)^2+\left(y-(1+(1+a)\cos T)\right)^2=a^2$$ where $T=\angle BCE+2\angle ECF=\arccos\left(\frac{1+p}{1+a}\right)+2\arcsin\left(\frac{a}{1+a}\right)$ . If we can show that $K$ is tangent to the lower right green circle, by showing that the discriminant equals $0$ , this would imply that $K$ is the right orange circle, which would imply that the right orange circle has radius $b$ , which is the radius of the red circle. Showing that the discriminant equals $0$ is extremely complicated. (Even if we let $p$ equal a specific number, for example $0$ , it is still very complicated.) But experimentation suggests that the red circle is indeed congruent with the orange circles. Hence the word "mysteriously" in the title. Context This question was inspired by my previous question , which also involves congruent circles in an isosceles triangle.
AcceptedAnswer:
Let right triangle $\triangle PQR$ be half of the isosceles triangle. Project the centers of (orange) $\bigcirc A$ , (green) $\bigcirc B_1$ and $\bigcirc B_2$ , (blue) $\bigcirc C_1$ , and (red) $\bigcirc D$ onto points $A'$ , $B_1'$ , $B_2'$ , $C_1'$ , $D'$ on hypotenuse $PQ$ . And define $\theta := \frac12\angle P$ . Let $\bigcirc C_2$ be the other (blue) circle congruent to $\bigcirc C_1$ , let $M$ and $O$ be the midpoints of segments $B_1B_2$ and $B_1'B_2'$ . To avoid the clutter of square root symbols, let radii of $\bigcirc A$ , $\bigcirc B_i$ , $\bigcirc C_i$ , and $\bigcirc D$ be $a^2$ , $b^2$ , $c^2$ , $d^2$ . One readily finds $$|PA'|=b^2\cot\theta \quad |A'B'|=2ab \quad
|B_1'O|=|OB_2'|=b^2 \quad
|B_2'C_1'|=2bc \quad
|C_1'D'|=2cd$$ Highlighted right triangles in the figure give rise to these relations $$\begin{align}
\tan2\theta &=\frac{ 2cd }{c^2 - d^2} \quad\to\quad \tan\theta=\frac{d}{c} \tag1 \\[6pt]
\tan2\theta &= \frac{b^2 + 2 b c}{|OC_2| - c^2} \tag2 \\[6pt]
\left(|OC_2| - b^2 \right)^2 + b^4 &= \left(b^2 + c^2 \right)^2 \tag3 \\[6pt]
|PO|=\quad |OC_2| \cot2\theta + c^2 \csc2\theta &= a^2 \cot\theta + 2 a b + b^2 \tag4
\end{align}$$ Using $(1)$ to eliminate $c$ from the remaining equations gives $$\begin{align}
b (b+2d\cot\theta) (\cot^2\theta-1) + 2 d^2 \cot^3\theta 
 - 2 |OC_2| \cot\theta &= 0 \tag{5} \\[6pt]
b^4 - 2 b^2d^2 \cot^2\theta - d^4\cot^4\theta - 2 b^2 |OC_2| + |OC_2|^2 &= 0 \tag{6}\\[6pt]
2 a^2 \cot^2\theta+ 4 a b \cot\theta + 2 b^2 \cot\theta
- d^2 \cot^2\theta(1+\cot^2\theta) 
+ |OC_2|(1 -\cot^2\theta) &= 0 \tag{7}
\end{align}$$ Using $(5)$ to eliminate $|OC_2|$ ... $$\begin{align}
b (1+ 2\cot\theta - \cot^2\theta) + 2d \cot\theta (1-\cot\theta) &= 0 \tag8 \\[6pt]
4 a^2 \cot^3\theta + 8 a b \cot^2\theta
-b^2 (1 - 6 \cot^2\theta + \cot^4\theta)
-2 b d \cot\theta (1 - \cot^2\theta)^2
-4 d^2 \cot^5\theta  &= 0 \tag9
\end{align}$$ (With $(8)$ , I discarded extraneous factors $b (b + 2d \cot\theta)(b (1 + 2 \cot\theta - \cot^2\theta) - 2 d \cot^2\theta (1 + \cot\theta))$ .) Finally, eliminating $b$ gives ... $$(a - d) \cdot \cot^3\theta (1 + 2 \cot\theta - \cot^2\theta) 
(a (1 + 2 \cot\theta - \cot^2\theta) - 
   d (3 - 6 \cot\theta + \cot^2\theta)) = 0 \tag{10}$$ I submit that all factors but the first are extraneous to the configuration indicated, so that we may conclude $a=d$ , confirming OP's "mysterious congruence". $\square$
